name: hold_em_bonus
description: A script for analyzing different betting strategies in Hold'em Bonus

commit.message: acknowledge that BruteForce Player exists, just don't use it
draw logic doesn't dictate betting gutters on the flop!
refactor PairsWithBoardDrawLogic
descriptively name players
ignore balances.png
generate Gruff graph of balances
track balance history
why did i need a hash?
track highest and lowest balance
Player4 bets like Player2 but any highest card, not just ace
create BruteForce Player (not in use due to slowness, though)
oh shit we push on a tie
Player3 incorporates draw logic
Player1 bets pairs or higher, Player2 also bets ace high
only bet ace high on the turn if the board is paired
only bet a pair if a hole card is included
import basic Game from other project

name: mangos
description: MaNGOS is a free, Open Source implementation of a game server compatible with the original World of Warcraft client.

[6990] Check creatures flags_extra for disable melee spells block/parry

[6984] Update crushing blow chance calculation for 3.0.3.

Required 4 level difference.
Player also can crushing blow if controlled and then considered as creature.

[6983] Revert [6978]. Useless for master branch. But ported to mangos-0.12 version will useful at branch.

* Remove unused arg of Unit::RollMeleeOutcomeAgainst and cleanup related code: Block crit implemented for spell by another way,
* Also comment out SPELL_AURA_IGNORE_COMBAT_RESULT aura check for block: not exist currently spell with this aura for bloc case.

[6982] Implemented gmlevel-based command security

This is just a simple check if target's gmlevel is lesser
than the caller's one. If it is, an error is returned.
Offline checks for some commands are included.

That in simple words means no further .goname to a gmlevel 3 player
from a gmlevel 2 or 1 account, so gmlevel 3 can work in peace.

[6830] Implement custom exit codes on server shutdown/restart

Added the possibility to use custom process return values
instead of hardcoded 0 (shutdown) or 2 (restart) to allow using them
for various custom external features / better handling.

This can be used through 4 commands in ".server" family:
 - shutdown
 - restart
 - idleshutdown
 - idlerestart

Those have from now on 2 arguments, where the second (return value)
is optional:

.server <command> <time> [return_value]

If return_value is not specified, default value (0 or 2) is used.

comments.body: frist??? I mean first :D
You don't need `@details.blank?` here with Yt :wink:

You might want to use `@details.embed_html` here, to get the HTML code of the IFRAME from YouTube:

`# => "<iframe type='text/html' src='http://www.youtube.com/embed/...' width='640' height='360' frameborder='0' allowfullscreen='true'/>"`
Publishing your secret keys on GitHub is a bad idea… :see_no_evil:
But in that case I cannot define specific width and height for the embed
You are right, I'm changing the implementation though. yt is amazing but is probably too much for what we are trying to do here
Oh yes, I should have defined a variable just for travis, my fault. I removed that keys from the google developer console to take the correct approach :)
Gracias :sparkling_heart:

issue.title: language variant codes are not handled
issue.body:
On top of the current limitations with language codes (issues #50 and #47), it appears jquery-localize doesn’t handle language variant codes (see section 2.2.5 of [BCP 47](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/bcp/bcp47.txt)).

An example of such a language code is "ca-ES-valencia", meaning the variant of Catalan spoken in the region of Valencia, Spain.

issue.title: image localization with jquery-localize
issue.body: Hi after several hours of work I finally found out how to localize images with this plugin. Say you want to have a different logo for every page then you have to define it: `html ` And then define it in your `application-en.json`. `javascript { "logo": { "src": "./path/to/logo-en.png", "alt": "logo" } } ` This way works with images, input field and all sorts of special html tags. Please add this to the docs so other people won't have a hard time finding it out. Thanks!

issue.title: Is it better to using 'key = elem.attr("data-localize");'?
issue.body:
In line [L98](https://github.com/coderifous/jquery-localize/blob/master/dist/jquery.localize.js#L98) The scenario is that there a element's data-localize will change by js. Then doing localize will cause issue example: ``` var a = $("
").attr("data-localize", 1); > undefined a > [
​
​] a.data() > Object {localize: 1} ``` if change the attr data-localize ``` a.attr("data-localize", 2) > [
​
​] a.data() > Object {localize: 1} a.attr("data-localize") > "2" ``` Now I use workaround in [my repository](https://github.com/JiYouMCC/FlightRisingTool/blob/gh-pages/js/fr.js#L169). The workaround seems so ugly... `$("#....").data("localize", newValue).attr("data-localize", newValue)`

issue.title: Localize parameters
issue.body:
As a developer I would appreciate if the plugin could use parameters so that I don't have to localize any strings with eg. numbers or other constant strings. In most cases it can be solved by separately localized "span" tags, but in particular cases such as "option" tags you can't. In this case localizing separately each string just because it differs only in the number is waste of space and developers time (not to mention it isn't very elegant). **Example:** **Localized JSON** { my_option: "My option {0}.{1}" } **HTML:**

<select>
<option data-localize="my_option" data-localize-params="1, 1"></option>
<option data-localize="my_option" data-localize-params="1, 2"></option>
<option data-localize="my_option" data-localize-params="2, 1"></option>
<option data-localize="my_option" data-localize-params="2, 2"></option>
<!-- etc. -->
</select>

**Result:** Select with options: _My option 1.1_ _My option 1.2_ _My option 2.1_ _My option 2.2_

issue.title: Setting placeholders to text containing utf-8 Latin1 Supplement chars
issue.body: We have a problem setting the placeholder of a text input field when the translated text contains non standard chars (for example ü in German translations). I already tried HTML encoding the char(ü) to ü and this works just fine for setting text input values and label values etc. but not for placeholder texts. I use a hidden input control which has the data-localize tag and then after localize function is called I set the placeholder texts by reading this hidden value. But for some reason the placeholder does not seem to decode the encoded text, I also tried setting the ü without encoding but this displays a � char.

issue.body: Add the bower configuration and register this packge in the bower registry.

issue.title: fall back logic for zh-xx
issue.body:
"zh-SG", "zh-CN" should fall back to "zh-HANS" (or "zh-CHS")
"zh-TW", "zh-HK", "zh-MO" should fall back to "zh-HANT" (or "zh-CHT")
"zh" is not a valid generic culture.

commit.message:
FS events layer should turn Pathnames into Strings.

runs before IRB starts up.

IRB.CurrentContext() method though.

Related #55.

/ping @lowjoel

Merge pull request #55 from lowjoel/master

Only deduce that we are in a console if IRB is loaded and there is an active session

Only deduce that we are in a console if IRB is loaded and there is an active session.

Some gems include parts of IRB but do not enable the console functionality (e.g. ruby-debug-ide).

Move RoutesLoadedFile into its own file.

This fixes an autoload issue, that happens if RoutesLoadedFile is

We have to be blunt and can't use a neat recursion.

With nested constants:

A::B::C
A::B::D

and explicit dependencies: {'A::B::C' => 'A'}

remove_const(A::B)
  -> remove_nested_const(A::B::C)
    -> remove_dependent_const(A)
      -> remove_nested_const(A::B) -- skipped because of prevent_further_removal_of)
      -> raw Dependencies.remove_const(A)
  -> remove_nested_const(A::B::D) -- skipped because it fails the qualified_const_defined? test as A namespace no longer exists

A::B::D const is thus left dangling.

issue.title: Async mode doesn`t work with NFS
issue.body:
Here is a basic application to illustrate that rails-dev-boost async doesn`t work with Vagrant: https://github.com/ablebeam/rails-dev-boost-vagrant-issue-example

Without rb-notify gem everything works correctly.

It seems, there is a very similar issue - https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/16678 but it is not related to rb-notify gem. Look like, that here is a description about this behavior: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21190584/vagrant-shared-folder-take-advantage-of-inotify-over-nfs

Maybe, this issues related to rb-notify etc, but I suppose it should be mentioned in rails-dev-boost limitation docs if it is really not possible to use with Vagrant.

issue.title: Patch ActiveSupport::FileUpdateChecker generically
issue.body:
I think it would give us a bit of a performance win if we switch all FileUpdateChecker reloaders generically. Another potentially slow bit of code in ActiveSupport is the code that checks for updated i18n files. In a large project, there could be many yaml files in the checker.

In my project, there are 57 files in the checker, leading to ~3100 IO operations per request (about 10% of total I/O operations)

I see that Sprockets takes a very long time as well, so maybe that can be patched somehow, but the way to do that is not obvious (to me)

issue.title: Constant unloaded but not using latest version after refresh
issue.body:
Hi,
I'm using Grape to serve an API with Rails 4 and my config looks like this:
application.rb:
    config.paths.add File.join('app', 'api'), glob: File.join('*_', '_.rb')
    config.autoload_paths += Dir[Rails.root.join('app', 'api', '*')]

My project structure is

```
app/
  api/
    base_api.rb
    v1/
      notification_api.rb
```

We mount grape in routes.rb as follow:

```
  mount BaseApi => '/api'
```

When debugging rails-dev-boost, I can see notification_api.rb being loaded in the constants.
If I modify the file, and perform another request, the debug! shows:

```
[DEV-BOOST] --- START ---
[DEV-BOOST] [CHANGED] #<LoadedFile /app/api/v1/notification_api.rb [V1::NotificationApi]>
[DEV-BOOST]   [SCHEDULE_DEPENDENT] #<LoadedFile /app/api/v1/notification_api.rb [V1::NotificationApi]>: #<LoadedFile /config/routes.rb []>
[DEV-BOOST]   [SCHEDULE_REMOVAL | SCHEDULED] V1::NotificationApi
[DEV-BOOST]     [SCHEDULE_CONTAINING_FILE] V1::NotificationApi -> #<LoadedFile /app/api/v1/notification_api.rb [V1::NotificationApi]>
[DEV-BOOST] [REMOVE_CONST] V1::NotificationApi
[DEV-BOOST] --- END ---
```

But the code being executed is still the old one. I debugged the gem and went through the code where my constant was removed. 

If I perform a second modification and another request, the constant is not loaded, and debug! shows:

```
[DEV-BOOST] --- START ---
[DEV-BOOST] --- END ---
```

So it looks like my NotificationApi is autoloaded fine at the start, it is unloaded on the first modification but never reloaded again.

@thedarkone, can you see something wrong in my setup?

issue.title: ModuleCache initializing takes a minute
issue.body:
I'm having problem where every reload is taking about a minute. With the debug mode on I was able to trace through the code to dependencies_patch Line: 115

Apparently iterating over ObjectSpace and mapping _mod_name takes a really long time.

For example, if I open up rails console and run 
`ObjectSpace.each_object(Module){|mod| mod._mod_name }` 

take about 100 seconds. The count returned is 26000+.

I've monkey patched Line 231 of same file `module_cache = nil` so that it doesn't reload the cache on every file reload. This improved the reload time significantly to around 1s, but I'm not sure what side effects I've introduced (I'm a ruby nub).

Any insights or point me to the right direction? Thanks!

issue.title: undefined method 'on_load' when loading v0.1.1; gem built incorrectly?
issue.body:
Hey there -

I believe that the gem was built incorrectly when it was pushed to rubygems last for version 0.1.1; when you do a fresh install of the gem like so:
gem install --version='0.1.1' rails-dev-boost

...and view the installed source code, the source is from the master branch (I think), and not the rails 2-3 branch. Specifically, line 2 of lib/rails_development_boost tries to call ActiveSupport.on_load, which is only present Rails 3 and above. This means that Rails can't load the gem, or even start the server. Sad day.

However, if I clone the repo, fetch the rails-2-3 branch, check it out, and then rebuild the gem myself manually, and install the gem, Rails loads correctly. So, I suspect that someone rebuilt the gem for version 0.1.1 when on the wrong branch of their checkout and uploaded it.

Is there any way we could get that corrected? I'd like to not keep the built gem checked into my own app repo.

Thanks!

commit.message:
mqlread now supports cursored queries

Pass :cursor => true to automatically batch the results for a query, sending multiple requests as necessary.
Useful for large resultsets that would time out if you fetch them in a single pass
mqlread should auto-create arrays of FreebaseResults when necessary

Don't bother version-controlling mql files

They're automatically regenerated during tests anyway, and aren't worth keeping a history of
Adding tests for mqlread

Add path information to MqlReadError

At the risk of making error messages even longer, 'path' seems more useful than 'code'

Fall through to super for method_missing

Gives much better error messages

Fixing up the example track types

Tracks come with a number of types (eg ["/common/topic", "/music/song", "/music/track", "/music/composition"])
At the moment, we create the object based only on its first type, so the example fails, because it doesn't define a formatted_length method on Common::Topic

Monkeypatching ActiveSupport::JSON's date bug

See http://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/1662-patch-json-decoder-date-converter-is-overeager
Updating test - The Police have 24 albums now
Updating cached fixture files

Hardcode /type/property type in load_schema

We're only interested in '/type/property's, and it works around the problems where multiple types are present (eg both /type/property & /common/foreign_key_property)

name: bookmarker
description: An old Tapestry 3 / Cayenne 1.1 Web app for managing bookmarks.

commit.message: Fixed a couple of bugs and added tooltips with category descriptions for the category selection tree.
Refactored the new tree code into its own package.  Sort the tree and bookmarks list alphabetically.  Removed the footer and allow the bookmarks list to scroll with the mousewheel in Firefox.
Replaced the contrib:Tree component with the tacos:Tree component.  The code is much easier to maintain now and I was able to generate much smaller URLs.
Moved Jetty configuration code into an XML file, which will make it much easier to customize.
Fix so the standalone version will bind to port 8080 on all addresses, not just 127.0.0.1.
Minor cleanups for the 0.2.1 release.
Missed a couple things.
Added a systray icon for controlling the server on Windows.
Updated Tapestry from 3.0.1 to 3.0.2 (with friendly URLs).  Updated version number to 0.2.1.
Added form validation.
Installer now works.
Some minor cleanups.    Toned down the logging level.  Sort things alphabetically now where I know how to.
Some minor clean-ups.
Removed the table from the footer.  Update the RDF file when a bookmark is removed.  Updated Bookmarker's version to 0.2 to reflect all the new changes.
The links delivered from the live bookmarks feed now increment the click count for a Bookmark.
Re-enabled the creation of the RDF file after updating the informa jar file to work with JDOM 1.0.
The importing of bookmarks actually work now.  Added some more i18n stuff.
Renamed the "Import" page to "LoadFile".
These were replaced by the friendly URL patched version of Tapestry 3.0.1
Moved the component classes to the correct location.
First take at an "import" page.  Updated the Border component to have more useful links.
Refactored the component classes into their own package.
Refactored the component classes into their own package.
Updated the Javadoc and comments in the source files.
Minor bug fixes.
Added a new service for exporting bookmarks.  Fixed the friendly URL-patched Tapestry jar.
Added a new service for exporting bookmarks.  Fixed the friendly URL-patched Tapestry jar.
Updated to use friendly URLs.
Added the t-deli ant task for auto-updating the application file with page locations.
Implemented the ability to change user authentication credentials.
Moved some pages around to make the organization a bit nicer.
Added the ability to do double password entry for typo verification in AuthUserPanel.
Moved the login panel into a new component, UserAuthPanel.  Started working on adding support for a UserAdmin page.
A couple bug fixes for the UI and updated the source files to use the "final" modifier wherever appropriate.
Updated the standalone version to use an extracted copy of the war file, since the webapp wasn't able to update bookmarks.rdf from within the war.
Fixed a bug causing an NPE when the "ViewBookmarks" page was accessed first.  Changed the context for the webapp running in standalone mode to better work with mod_jk2.
Apparently the build script didn't quite work with ant v1.6.2.  This should fix the problem.
Start up an AJP13 listener now, for use with mod_jk.  Downgraded the Jetty libs to 4.2.2 since they're the only ones I can get to work right now.
Updated footer with version info and link to project page.  Added the date an item was added to the RDF file.  Started to update the build process to allow arbitrary db directory names.
Added some comments.  Correctly set an item's author in the RDF file.  Don't deploy by default in the ant build file (this way deploying to Tomcat is optional, not required).
Fixed a couple bugs.  Bookmarks with no associated category display now.  Increased the "description" text field size for the add/modify bookmarks page.
Updated the Jetty libs to the ones from Jetty 5.1.0.  Added license files for the third party libs I'm distributing.
Licensed bookmarker under the ASL 2.0.
First take at an installer for Windows.
Finally a cayenne jar file with the fixed auto-db generation ant task.  Updated the build.xml file to not use deprecated tasks.
Updated to fix a small bug in the cayenne db generator task.
Updated the eclipse classpath file.
Implemented a way to logout of the system.  Externalized a couple strings that were not externalized.
Auto-add an admin user if no users are in the system.  This feels like a hack, but it's a necessary evil for now.
Another big batch of changes.  Added user support in the DB (essentially this will facilitate multi-user support) and added some more attributes to bookmarks and categories.

Big changes.  The app is set up to be wholly contained now.  The db has been switched to hsqldb and the ant script will auto-generated the db.  The app can be run as a WAR in an existing servlet container or can run on its own using a local copy of jetty.

Added the ability to edit bookmarks.  Updated the login system to redirect you to the page the user was visiting prior to logon.  Created a new class for the Border to better handle some things (Border now has its own listeners).

Added ability to delete bookmarks (this will probably have to change to be more secure).  Also updated the ant script to copy the log4j.properties file to someplace actually useful.  Added some Tapestry logging options to log4j.properties.
UI updates.  Changed default db name for cayenne.  Updated the Informa lib to one I built from CVS.  General fix-ups.

Added a file necessary for Cayenne.  Removed the bookmarks.rdf file from SVN, since I keep committing changes I make to it, although it should be blank.  Now ant will just auto-create the file for me.
Some more UI changes.
Better integrated the login page.  Removed tables from input forms (all CSS stuff now).
Starting to move to a pure CSS layout.
Added the non-overwritten auto-generated files to svn.
First take at storing links in an RDF file and using FireFox's live bookmarks feature.
Added a very rough initial implementation of a restricted access system.
Added a new exception page that helps pinpoint the problem.  Also updated a number of third party jars.
Fixed a bug with the build script.  Added the ability to track how many times a link has been clicked.
Removed some code duplication in building the category tree.
Handle children in the tree much better now.
Now the category tree remembers state across pages.
Initial import.

comments.body: should read activesupport, not active_support, active_support is not an official gem is is pointing to an ancient version of activesupport.

issue.title: Remove null byte from proctitle
issue.body:
Null bytes cause problems with NewRelic RPM:

ERROR : Failed to harvest profile_data data, resetting. Error:
ERROR : ArgumentError: string contains null byte

This happens because File.basename raises an exception when the string
contains a null byte.

According to @ageweke in 32791ce1531a8cf9f533254204694915394fecba using
a null byte is no longer necessary. I have not found any examples online
that use the null byte.

issue.title: Fixes 'Unhandled exception: no implicit conversion of Pathname into S…
issue.body:
…tring (TypeError)' exception when running on Ruby 2.2.2.

I spotted the above issue after upgrading our Rails app to Ruby 2.2.2.  Concatenating a Pathname to a String, no longer 'casts' the Pathname to a String.  You either need to call Pathname#to_s, or use File#join.  I opted for the latter - hope it helps.

issue.title: postgres dropping connections from workers with "unterminated quoted string in connection info string"
issue.body:
If you set process name to something containing \0 you will not be able to connect to postgres.
Easy to reproduce:

```
2.0.0-p247 :007 >   $0 = "foo bar\0"
 => "foo bar\u0000"
2.0.0-p247 :008 > require 'pg'; PGconn.connect(dbname: "postgres")
PG::ConnectionBad: unterminated quoted string in connection info string
```

https://github.com/kovyrin/loops/blob/master/lib/loops/worker.rb#L39 — here it is set.

def subscribes
  subscribe Handler, :exchange_name => "exch",

issue.title: Newer libmemcached doesn't like keys with no length.
issue.body:
Previous versions of libmemcached would prepend the namespace to
a zero length key before submitting it to memcached.

Now it just returns an error, so don't attempt to call get_multi()
with such keys.

issue.title: Tagging releases on github
issue.body:
Hi,

For distro package maintainers it's nice to be able to quickly find the version of the source that we package from hackage. It's useful for applying bugfixes and security patches if needed. Doing a git blame on the version string doesn't tell us if the next commit is also part of the release without manually checking the changes.

Thank you,
David

issue.title: Update Ceases To Function When Quote Met
issue.body:
Finally had a chance to make use of this great plugin and ran into an unfortunate situation while testing. Here's the scenario...

host.plan.item_limit = 5
4.times do Item.create = Success
Item.update_attributes = Success
Item.create = Success
Item.update_attributes = Failed "Quota met: 5, please upgrade your plan to add more."

Not only does meeting the quota prevent the 5th item from being updated, it prevents ALL items from being updated. Seems like the best way to fix would be to only run validate_limits on a new_record. Here's a really simple workaround

lib/limit_by_scope.rb line 43

def validate_limits
  if new_record?
    errors.add_to_base("#{limit_error}") unless self.class.limit.blank? || self.class.limit > self.class.count
  end
end

name: google-toolbox-for-mac
description: This is a just a copy of google-toolbox-for-mac code base.

commit.message:
- Updated some tests for 10.5.6.
- Updated some tests for debug vs. release differences.  (added help on log
  validation for this).
- Some fixes build issues w/ different os versions.

- GTMStackTrace works on 10.5+ (and iPhone) using NSThread to build the call stack.

- Added GTM_EXTERN that makes it easier to mix and match objc and objc++ code.

- Added GTMHotKeysTextField for display and editing of hot key settings.

- Added GTMCarbonEvent for dealing with Carbon Events and HotKeys in a ObjC like way.

- Backported the Atomic Barrier Swap functions for Objective C back to Tiger.

- Added a variety of new functions to GTMUnitTestingUtilities for checking if the screensaver is in the way, waiting on user events, and generating  keystrokes.

- If you are using any Carbon routines that log (DebugStr, AssertMacros.h) and use GTMUnitTestDevLog, the log routines now go through _GTMDevLog so that they can be caught in GTMUnitTestDevLog and verified like any _GTMDevLog calls you may make. For an example of this in action see GTMCarbonEventTest.m.

- Added GTMFileSystemKQueue.  It provides a simple wrapper for kqueuing something in the file system and tracking changes to it.

- RunIPhoneUnitTest.sh now cleans up the user home directory and creates a documents directory within it, used when requesting a NSDocumentDirectory.

- Added GTMNSFileManager+Carbon which contains routines for path <-> Alias conversion and path <-> FSRef conversion.

- Added GTMNSArray+Merge for merging one array into another with or without a custom merging function, returning a new array with the merged contents.

- fix up some style things.
- change the api slightly so things are a little more "cocoa-y".

Fixing the use of the wrong var w/ the failure selector.
  (http://code.google.com/p/google-toolbox-for-mac/issues/detail?id=10)

- Added GTMLightweightProxy
- Added installer for the spotlight importers.

- Added has ability to check if a script has an open handler to GTMNSAppleScript+Handler.
- GTMStackTrace support for building a trace from the call stack in an NSException (for 10.5+ and iPhone).
- Added GTMUIFont+LineHeight.
- Cleaned up some OS version checks to use constants instead of numbers directly.

- Update iphone address book radars.
- Fix for issue 7 GTMABMutableMultiValue instantiation returns nil.

- GTM_INLINE will make sure a function gets inlined, and provides a consistent
  way for all GTM code to do it.

- Added GTMDebugThreadValidation to allow you to enforce the fact that your
  code must run in the main thread in DEBUG builds.

- Updated some internals of the iPhone unittesting so it doesn't double print
  the test descriptions, file names, or lines numbers of a test failure line.
  Also includes the test names in the error output.

- Changed the xcconfigs so that know it's easier to set different settings at
  the different levels and not accidentally overwrite settings set at lower
  levels in the "settings collapse". Also tightened up warnings significantly.

- Changed how gtm_unitTestExposedBindingsTestValues works. If you have an
  implementation of gtm_unitTestExposedBindingsTestValues in your own code
  you will need to update to the new way of calling. See implementations in
  GTMNSObject+BindingUnitTesting.m for details.

- Added support for grabbing the build number for a particular OS in
  GTMSystemVersion and easily comparing it to known build numbers, and switched 
  some types from in GTMSystemVersion from "int" to SInt32 to make 64 bit work 
  better.
   
- Added support for SnowLeopard (10A96). We build cleanly with the 10.6 SDKs and
  all radar checks were updated accordingly. Build All script was also updated
  to build on SnowLeopard if you have the SDK available.
  
- Turned off building ppc64 GTM because the SnowLeopard SDK currently
  doesn't have ppc64 support, so SenTestCase isn't defined. This makes it
  impossible to build the ppc64 10.5 config on SnowLeopard. We have left the
  setting in the xcconfig for those of you who need it, but have disabled
  it in the GTM project settings.
  
- Turned on stack smashing protection on the debug builds for all Leopard 
  and above.

- Added ability to easily do leak checking by defining the GTM_ENABLE_LEAKS
  environment variable. It isn't on by default because several of Apple's
  frameworks leak. You can work around these false positives by using the
  GTM_LEAKS_SYMBOLS_TO_IGNORE environment variable. Also if you turn on leaks
  make sure to turn off zombies by defining the GTM_DISABLE_ZOMBIES variable,
  otherwise every memory allocation you do will look like a leak.
fix double printing of failures on the iphone unittests

added missing comment in release notes (forgot to hit safe).
remove the reference from the GTM project to the iPhone one (doesn't work and
  the script target works instead).

- Added GTMTestTimer.h for doing high fidelity timings.
 
- Added leaks checking to iPhone unit test script. It can be controlled by
  the GTM_DISABLE_LEAKS environment variable

- Added ability to control using zombies to iPhone unit test script. It can be
  controlled by the GTM_DISABLE_ZOMBIES environment variable

- Added ability to control termination to iPhone unit test script. It can be
  controlled by the GTM_DISABLE_TERMINATION environment variable

- Fixed several leaks found with leak checking enabled.

- Added configs for different iPhone OS versions.

- Added GTMExceptionalInlines for dealing with cases where you get
  warning: variable 'r' might be clobbered by 'longjmp' or 'vfork'
  when using certain Apple inlined functions in @synchronized/@try blocks.
  
- Updated to Xcode 3.1 so the GTM and iPhone project have the same baseline.
  The code should work in other version of xcode, but the projects and
  xcconfig files now use 3.1 features.

- Added GTMABAddressBook which is a cocoa wrapper for the 'C' AddressBook
  APIs on the iPhone.

- Added several set environment variable statements to RunIPhoneUnitTest.sh
  to encourage bugs to come out of the woodwork.

- add svn:ignore properties in a few places.
- fix up the test script so the resource fork can exists after svn.
- add schema files to the importers that needed them.
- change how we launch ibtool so it won't create zombies.

- Added GTMGetURLHandler class that gives you a very easy way of supporting
  Get URL events just by adding a key to your plists, and adding a single
  method to your class. See GTMGetURLHandler.m for more details.

- Added XcodeProject, AppleScript, and InterfaceBuilder Spotlight Plugins. 
  Allows you to index .xcodeproj, .scpt, .scptd, .xib, .nib, and 
  .aib files. See Readmes beside individual projects in SpotlightPlugins.

- Added GTMNSMakeUncollectable for forcing objects to survive in a GC world.
 
- Added GTMCFAutorelease to make the [GTMNSMakeCollectable(cfFoo) autorelease] simpler and clearer, it's now just GTMCFAutorelease(cfFoo), and works in both GC and non-GC world.

- Added GTMIsGarbageCollectionEnabled to GTMGarbageCollection.h.  See the note there for it's usage.

- Disabled the unittests for things on top of NSAppleScript in a GC world since Apple has bugs and it can crash.  See the unittest for a note about it.

- GTMStackTrace now can figure out ObjC symbols. Downside it is now ObjC only.

- GTMFourCharCode can now be used with NSAppleEventDescriptors easily. typeType, typeKeyword, typeApplSignature, and typeEnumerated all get turned into GTMFourCharCodes.

- Fixed up crash in GTMLoggerRingBufferWriter when used with GC on.

- Significant updates to GTMNSAppleScript+Handler allowing you to list all handlers and properties (including inherited) and cleans up several errors in how scripting was being handled.

fix a bug w/ method check support.
mark part of the logger+asl code as not feasible for testing.
work around a unittesting marco catch w/ gc and __weak.
helps if I add the files before doing the commit

- Removed GTMNSWorkspace+ScreenSaver as it has always been a little dodgy due
  to it's dependencies on undocumented frameworks, and the ScreenSaver
  framework doesn't play nicely in GC mode.
- Added property methods to GTMHTTPFetcher.  These are convenient alternatives
  to storing an NSDictionary in the userData.
- Renamed GTMDevLog.m to GTMDevLogUnitTestingBridge.m and added some more
  comments where it comes into play to hopefully make it more clear that it
  isn't needed in most cases.
- Fixed a potential GTMHTTPFetcher crash on failed authentication.
- Added a obj-c logging package, GTMLogger, for applications that want an
  application level logging system.  See GTMLogger.h, GTMLogger+ASL.h, and
  GTMLoggerRingBufferWriter.h for what the basic system and two optional
  additions can do.

- Added GTMSignalHandler for simple signal handling (via kqueue/runloop).
- Fixed up GTMIPhoneUnitTestDelegate to be pickier about which tests it runs
- Added GTMNSString+URLArguments to GTMiPhone
- Added GTMHTTPFetcher and GTMHTTPServer to GTMiPhone
- Made sure that build would work with iPhone device attached, and that all 
  tests run directly on the phone.
- Added GTMValidatingContainers which are a set of mutable container classes 
  that allow you to have a selector on a target that is called to verify that 
  the objects being put into the container are valid. This can be controlled 
  at compile time so that you don't take the performance hit in a release build.
- Added GTMPath, which represents an existing absolute path on the file system.
  It also makes it very easy to contruct new paths in the file system as well
  as whole directory hierarchies.
- Added GTMNSString+Replace for a common replacement need.
- Added NSString+FindFolder for two commen helpers for building paths to common
  locations.
- Added GTMLargeTypeWindow for doing display windows similar to Address Book
  Large Type display for phone numbers.
fix building tiger gcov in directories w/ spaces in the name
update release notes to say 1.5.0

Landing a log of AppleScript/AppleEvent support code.
Landing GTMHTTPServer as a simple server but mainly for use in unittesting.
_GTMCompileAssert for doing compile time assertions to GTMDefines.h
Lots of improvments for UnitTesting, Dave's gonna put up a wiki page shortly with the full details of what can be done.

Standardize the reverse dns names for errors, notifications, etc.
iPhone unit test framework didn't run tearDown on failures.
Add String and Dictionary URLArgument support and tests.

Added missing test image.
Export a header that was left as Project instead of Public.

fix a iphone unittesting problem.
add stack trace.

Flush out suppport for 64bit, GC support.
Added some more xcode configs related to the above.
Removed some classes that the unittesting doesn't need (and aren't able to
  support 64bit).
add base64, httpfetcher, and progress monitor stream.
removing executable bit that shouldn't be set
removed the executable bit set by accident on a few files
adding ignore for xcode breadcrumbs
helps to hit save in your editor

See the ReleaseNotes for the full details, highlights:
- bug fixes
- code coverage support
- more complete unittests
- full support for unittesting UIs
- support for the iphone sdk (include ui unittesting)
Added GTMNSWorkspace+ScreenSaver, and got rid of device colors.

switch the helper on NSTask over to a static function incase anyone ever wanted
  to use this code in some plugin where categories get dangerous.
Added GTMNSFileManager+Path for two small helpers.

Found and fixed a bug in the regex enumerators that was causing them to
 incorrectly walk a string when using '^' in an expression.
Added GTMScriptRunner for spawning scripts.

- Fixed up the prefix header of the project and prefix handing in the Unittest
  Xcode Config. (thanks schafdog)
- Fixed error in handling default compression for NSData+zlib
- Changed name on API in NSString+XML and added another api to make this a
  litte more clear. (thanks Kent)
fold in GTMRegex and ignore the build dir
use the better testing macro so failures log

commit.message: Make loader work for application/xhtml+xml served documents. [#95 state:resolved]
Check for Windows Media plugin and RealPlayer plugin in Firefox on Windows to allow sound playback. [#86 state:resolved]
Remove dead code in effects.js. [#125 state:resolved]
Update to Prototype 1.6.0.3, prep 1.8.2 release
Revert added semicolons to effects.js. Add .gitignore. Cleanup trailing spaces and newlines at end of files.
Make sure InPlaceEditor converts HTML entities to text.
InPlaceEditor will correctly show text with ampersands upon edit (no more &)
add changelog entry
added all missing semicolons
added some missing semicolons
Fix that Builder.node did not return extended elements on IE. [#71 state:resolved] [#77 state:resolved]
Fix a bug in Sortable.destroy to make sure it's called on the referenced Sortable only, which allows for the correct intialization of nested Sortables. Closes Trac #8615.  [Leon Chevalier]
Change Effect.Base#render not to use eval(), so certain JavaScript runtime environments (like Adobe AIR) that do not support eval() work. [King Maxemilian, John-David Dalton] [#20 state:resolved]

Fixed a calculation error in Effect.Transitions.pulse that could lead to flickering, add easing and change it to be a normal 0 to 1 transition that can be used with any effects; Effect.Pulsate now uses its own implementation.
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/staaky/scriptaculous
link to scriptaculous twitter account in README
Fixed Effect.ScrollTo.
Update Prototype version check so all version can be required and use $$ in the loader instead of getElementsByTagName.  Closes #9032, #10966  [Nick Stakenburg]
Update years in copyright statements.
Merge branch 'master' of git://github.com/jdalton/scriptaculous
Added missing semi-colons for code consistency (side note it helps with a ton of compression), but main reason is code onsistency *wink
Take advantage of githubs rdoc rendering for the README file.
bumped year in license

Ruby 1.8 and 1.9 compatibility.
Changing ignore globs into a regex union, allows 50+% speedups.

Handle VIM.evalute tripping over null string.

VIM.evaluate changed its API in early March 2010.  Unfortunately the
change introduced a bug where null (in Vim-land) strings cause an error
when Vim tries to convert them to a Ruby string.

Handle VIM.evaluate's API change.

Previously VIM.evaluate always returned a string.  From early March
2010, it returns a value of the appropriate type (array, hash, etc).

name: couchdb-editing-session
description: Simple layer, built on python-couchdb, that caches fetched documents and provides an editing session by accumulating all changes into a single bulk upload.

commit.message: Add datetime types to list of immutable types that don't need tracking.
Wrap items when iterating a list.
Fix typo
Test dict.update() ... just in case

Track None and long instances as immutable, i.e. don't bother tracking
them.
Add a reset() method to clear down the session.
Oops, only committed the "git mv" on the directory!
Rename package to couchdbsession.
Rename to couchdb-session.
Test providing flush hooks as args or by subclassing.

Extend the sesson to have pre and post flush hooks.

The signature of the flush hooks is the same, it's just when the hook
gets called that changes.

A pre flush hook is useful when everything you need to do is in memory,
i.e. you don't need to look at the content of the CouchDB. A post flush
hook is used when the state of the CouchDB affects the processing, i.e.
if you rely on a view.
Avoid unnecessary calls to couchdb.
Don't bother tracking changes to new documents.

Don't create new dict instances to pass to couchdb-python, pass the
__subject__ instead.

Avoid JSON encoding problems by never passing wrapped docs to
couchdb-python.

Add tests highlighting JSON encoding problem.

simplejson uses type checking to decide what encoder to call.
Unfortunately, the a8n.Dictionary doesn't look like a dict to simplejson
... even though isinstance(o, dict) says True.

Revert "Remove use of ProxyTypes."

This reverts commit ad59bb5ba3bc077261058f912f9b372b00c0bc3a.

It turns out that working on copies of object is never gonna work ...
well, duh!
Use temp database.
Expose the Session at the package level.
Make the whole thing a proper package.

Remove use of ProxyTypes.

It was getting in the way of simplejson's encoding, and it's not really
needed now anyway.

Call a hook function, passing all the changes, to a hook function before
actually writing to the database.

The hook function may make additional changes (that's what it's for in
fact) and so the state of the session needs to be "frozen" before the
hook is called and then checked for additional changes.

The total set of updates to write to CouchDB is all of the changes made
during the session and during all the pre-flush hook calls.
Add track() dispatch methods for immutable types.
Wrap ViewResults.rows, to detect .doc access.
Rename track() dispatch method to give it a unique name.
Make the tests pass ... enough for now.

Wire up trackers in the editing session move all "dirty" state tracking
to the tracker instance.

Special-case tracking a couchdb.Document so we don't record changes to
_rev and potentially other "private" attributes.

Move the track() generic func to the Tracker instance to avoid
unnecessary Recorder creation.

Immutable objects don't need a Recorder instance but the old track()
functions required a Recorder instance as an arg. Leaving it to the
Tracker instance means it can create a Recorder only if needed, i.e. not
for immutable objects.

The Recorded has also become starting to track child objects, although
it was basically doing that already but more along the lines of "create
me a recorder I can use" instead of "track this, please". Nicer, I
think.

Add a 'dirty_callback' to the Tracker that is called the first time a
change is detected.
Remove old, commented out tests.

Track the previous or removed value ('was') so the actual change is
obvious.

For instance a change to a string in a dict, from 'foo' to 'bar', looks
like:

  {'action': 'edit',
   'path': [..., 'string'],
   'value': 'bar',
   'was': 'foo'}

Unfortunately, the 'was' value must be the value when the document was
loaded, i.e. any changes made to the value up to the point it's removed
must be undone.

Now, we do have the steps to undo the change ... but ...  yikes!

Test that changes to a nested obj are forgotten if the obj is replaced
or removed.

Don't track changes to objects added to the tracked object graph.

Basically, a newly added dict or list can and should be treated as a
simple value and not have changes made to it tracked.
Test combinations of operations on tracked lists.
Track and test combinations of operations on dicts.
Update paths during list's __delitem__, insert, pop and remove.
Move private func out of the way

Move knowledge of the object's path into the tracker instance and fix
paths to make the (one and only) "nasty" test pass.

Abstract access to the tracker via a per-object recorder.

The recorder manages the path on behalf of the tracked object and
provides a nice API (create(), edit(), remove()) for the tracked object.

Critically, relieving the tracked object of managing the path allows the
path to be changed in a central location, e.g. when an item is removed
from a list the following items need their paths "fixed".
Add example of nastiness.

WIP ... giving up for now.

There are a number of problems here.

Firstly, I need to track the old value of changed items so that
referencing docs can be located. That's not a big problem; just means a
small extension to the diff document I'm already building.

However, as the object graph is retrieved the path used to locate the
object is constructed. Unfortunately, since Python's lists are mutable
those paths cannot be trusted to remain the same. For instance:

doc = {'list': [{}, {}]}
a_dict = doc['list'][1]   # has path ['list', 1]
del doc['list'][0]
a_dict['foo'] = 'foo' # path is ['list', 1] but should be ['list', 0]

a_dict could even have been removed from the document altogether - del
doc['list'][1] - in which case it should not record any changes.

Simplify cache management for deleted docs.

The document was left in the cache so we had the _rev for when it came
to build the _bulk_docs request. However, I changed _deleted to be a
dict mapping _id to _rev, instead of a set.

That simplfies cache checks and simplifies clean up during flush.

Add test for and fix creating a document with the id of a deleted
document.
Fix creation with known doc id.
Re-implement __getitem__ using get().

Split out tests to own module and fix import.

Running the tests from the same module as the tested code was masking an
import error - I hadn't import the uuid module.

The tests have now been split out to ensure it doesn't happen again.
Remove unnecesary import
Don't send update for a changed, then deleted document.
Not sure what that file was
Added a quick README to get started and jot down some notes.

Combine into a single module until I can be bothered to package things
better.
Add __setitem__ support.
(Reluctantly) support __delitem__.
Add rest of pure forwarding to underlying db.
Organise the Session methods a little better.
Start testing (and fixing) the calls straight out to couchdb's Database.
Suport document deletion.
Slightly improved comment
Support new document creation.
Ignore .pyc files

Implement storing, aka flushing, of documents that have been changed
during the editing session.

Track modified documents.

Documents, dicts in documents and lists in documents are now wrapped.
Any changes made to anything in the document notify the session that the
document has been modified via a callback function.
Ignore vim .swp files.

Initial cut at an "editing context" over couchdb.

So far, only the basic shell of the system is really written.

However, it already supports getting documents from the database in
various (all?) different ways and caches retrieved documents for the
lifetime of the editing context.

commit.message: bump version and push to gemcutter
Clean up broken requires

merge
add project memberships and project tags
Change the gemspec a little to pass the github-test gist.

Add the Version inner class to Lighthouse::Ticket.

This is to make it possible to YAML.load a .to_yaml'ed ticket in a
new session.  If no ticket has been loaded from Lighthouse yet, then
the Lighthouse::Ticket::Version class doesn't exist, and YAML.load
treats the Version objects as bags of attributes.  Adding the Version
inner class means it's always available, and we can use the #user_id
and similar accessors, even on loaded objects.

There may be other classes that need the same treatment, but the Version
inner class is extremely important, so it's the first one I ran into.
